questions.prompt: A space X is connected if and only if:
options: X cannot be written as a union of two disjoint nonempty open sets
Every continuous function f: X → {0, 1} is constant
X cannot be separated into disjoint open sets AND every map to {0, 1} is constant
questions.explanation: X is connected iff it cannot be separated into two disjoint nonempty open sets, which is equivalent to every continuous function to the discrete space {0, 1} being constant. Both conditions characterize connectedness.

questions.prompt: Every path connected space is connected.
questions.explanation: True. Path connectedness implies connectedness. However, the converse is false (e.g., the topologist's sine curve).

questions.prompt: Which of the following is connected in ℝ with standard topology?
questions.explanation: [0, 2] is connected (all intervals in ℝ are connected). The other options can be separated into disjoint open sets.

questions.prompt: The continuous image of a connected space is connected.
questions.explanation: True. Connectedness is preserved by continuous functions. If f: X → Y is continuous and X is connected, then f(X) is connected.

questions.prompt: A connected component of a space X is:
options: The largest connected subset containing a point
questions.explanation: The connected component of x is the maximal connected set containing x. Every point belongs to exactly one connected component.

questions.prompt: ℝ \ {0} is connected in the standard topology.
questions.explanation: False. ℝ \ {0} = (-∞, 0) ∪ (0, ∞) is disconnected. It can be written as two disjoint nonempty open sets.

questions.prompt: If A ⊆ B ⊆ cl(A) and A is connected, then:
options: cl(A) may or may not be connected
B may or may not be connected
B must be connected, and so must cl(A)
Only B must be connected, but cl(A) may not be
questions.explanation: If A is connected and A ⊆ B ⊆ cl(A), then B is connected. In particular, the closure of a connected set is connected.

options: Continuous functions map connected sets to connected sets
If f: [a,b] → ℝ is continuous and f(a) < c < f(b), then c is in the range
questions.explanation: IVT: If f is continuous on [a,b] and f(a) < c < f(b), then ∃x ∈ (a,b) with f(x) = c. This follows from connectedness of intervals.

questions.prompt: A space is totally disconnected if its only connected subsets are singletons.
questions.explanation: True. In a totally disconnected space, the connected components are precisely the singleton sets. Example: ℚ with subspace topology from ℝ.
The Cantor set is totally disconnected. The others are all connected (in fact, path connected).

questions.prompt: A space X is locally connected if:
options: Every connected component is closed but not necessarily open
Every point has arbitrarily small connected neighborhoods
questions.explanation: X is locally connected iff every point has a local basis of connected sets (i.e., arbitrarily small connected neighborhoods), which is equivalent to connected components of open sets being open.

questions.prompt: Every connected space is locally connected.
questions.explanation: False. The topologist's sine curve is connected but not locally connected. Connectedness is global; local connectedness is a local property.

options: Equivalence classes under the path-equivalence relation
questions.explanation: Path components are equivalence classes where x ~ y if there's a path connecting them. They may not equal connected components.

questions.prompt: If X and Y are connected, then X × Y is connected.
questions.explanation: True. The product of connected spaces is connected. This extends to arbitrary products by Tychonoff-like arguments.

questions.prompt: Which space is connected but not path connected?
questions.explanation: The topologist's sine curve {(x, sin(1/x)) : x > 0} ∪ {(0, y) : -1 ≤ y ≤ 1} is connected but not path connected.
